title: Practice Challenge
description: Practice using the C# 13 implicit 'from end' index (^) in object initializers.
instructions:
Create a countdown display using the ^ operator in object initializers!

1. Create a class called 'Countdown' with a public int[] Numbers property initialized to size 5
2. Create an instance using object initializer with ^ operator:
   - Set [^1] = 1 (last position)
   - Set [^2] = 2 (second-to-last)
   - Set [^3] = 3 (third-to-last)
   - Set [^4] = 4
   - Set [^5] = 5 (first position)
3. Display all numbers using a foreach loop
4. Also display using ^1 index: 'Last number is: X'

The result should show: 5, 4, 3, 2, 1

testCases.description: Output should show the sequence with 5

hints.text: The ^ operator counts from the end. ^1 is the last element, ^2 is second-to-last, etc.
In object initializers, use the syntax: Numbers = { [^1] = value, [^2] = value }. Note the curly braces after the property name!
Remember: ^0 is OUT OF BOUNDS! It means 'one past the end'. The last valid element is ^1.

commonMistakes.consequence: ^0 means 'one past the end' and throws IndexOutOfRangeException! The last element is ^1, not ^0.
commonMistakes.correction: Use ^1 for last, ^2 for second-to-last, etc.

commonMistakes.consequence: [1] is the SECOND element (index 1 from start), while [^1] is the LAST element. Without ^, you're indexing from the front!
commonMistakes.correction: Always include ^ when indexing from the end: [^1], [^2], etc.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using ^ outside object initializers in older C# versions
commonMistakes.consequence: The ^ operator has been available since C# 8, but using it in OBJECT INITIALIZERS is new in C# 13. Make sure your project targets .NET 9.
commonMistakes.correction: Ensure your project uses C# 13 / .NET 9 for object initializer support
